Testing the effectiveness of virtual reality as a defusion technique for coping with unwanted thoughts
Download PDF
Download PDF
  • Original Article
  • Published: 08 November 2018

Testing the effectiveness of virtual reality as a defusion technique for coping with unwanted thoughts

  • Arianna Prudenzi1,
  • Brendan Rooney1,
  • Giovambattista Presti2,
  • Marco Lombardo3,
  • Daniele Lombardo3,
  • Concetta Messina2 &
  • Louise McHugh1 

Virtual Reality volume 23, pages179–185(2019)Cite this article

  • 431 Accesses

  • 1 Citations

  • 24 Altmetric

  • Metrics details

Abstract

Negative thoughts are experienced by as many as 80–99% of the population. These thoughts are associated with a variety of negative consequences, including negative mood, decreased task performance and the development of psychopathology. One technique employed in contextual behavioral therapies to help cope with negative thoughts is cognitive defusion. Cognitive defusion techniques undermine potential negative effects of thinking by teaching clients to get some distance from their thoughts. Virtual reality (VR) is the computer-generated simulation of a three-dimensional environment that users can interact in. VR is of increasing interest to applied psychologists due to its potential for exposure learning. One area where VR may be effective is helping people to cope with negative thoughts. The current study examined the impact of a VR task as a cognitive defusion technique on participants’ relationship with a negative self-referential thought (e.g., “I am a failure”). Thirty participants were randomly assigned to one of two conditions (i.e., defusion VR and control VR). Participants were tested pre- and post-VR task on a state measure of cognitive defusion and ratings of their self-referential negative thought. The results indicated that a defusion VR task facilitates the management of negative thoughts and leads to an increase in state defusion. The findings are discussed in terms of their implications for the use of VR techniques in dealing with negative thoughts.

Introduction

Negative thoughts are experienced by as many as 80–99% of the non-clinical population (Rachman and de Silva 1978; Belloch et al. 2004). They are defined as any distinct and identifiable thoughts that are unwanted, unintended and recurrent (Clark and Rhyno 2005). Such thoughts are associated with a variety of negative consequences, including negative mood, interrupted flow of thought and decreased task performance (Clark and Rhyno 2005). They are also believed to be involved in the development of psychopathology (Clark and Rhyno 2005). The high prevalence of negative thoughts and their link with more serious psychological problems have prompted the development of different techniques to help individuals to deal with them. Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (ACT; Hayes et al. 1999) is a contextual behavioral therapy that has been widely adopted and the focus of an increasing number of clinical trials during recent years (see Gaudiano 2011 for a review). The ACT process that is most relevant to coping with unwanted thoughts is cognitive defusion. Cognitive defusion involves undermining negative effects of thinking by teaching clients to get some distance from their thoughts, by altering their verbal context. Subjectively, defusion is experienced as “having” thoughts and feelings rather than “being” thoughts and feelings (Atkins and Styles 2016).

In general, the process of cognitive defusion weakens the function of thoughts, by altering the meaning of the words and transferring them into a different context from where they usually manifest. Although not included in a clinical treatment protocol, Masuda et al. (2004) conducted the first experimental study examining the impact of a repetition technique measuring the believability associated with a disturbing thought. Believability is the degree to which people consider a thought to be real and true. Results showed that the defusion technique had a significant effect on reducing believability in comparison with the control condition.

Larsson et al. (2016) investigated the efficacy of a defusion, restructuring or control strategy for managing personally relevant self-referential thoughts over a five-day period in a non-clinical adult population. They found that defusion significantly lowered the believability of the generated target thought and increased comfort and willingness to have the thought (Larsson et al. 2016). Similar trends in the results were observed for pre-generated positive and negative self-statements (Larsson et al. 2016). There are a variety of different techniques that facilitate defusion in the ACT literature. Examples of such techniques include a high pace word repetition (Masuda et al. 2004), altering the tone of voice (Larsson et al. 2016), visualizing thoughts during mindfulness practice (Hayes et al. 2011), and putting the thought in the context of sentences like “my mind is suggesting…”, or “I’m having the thought…” (Healy et al. 2008). The main focus of these techniques is to alter the literal context of the sentence not to hinder, minimize or ridicule the thought, but to offer a way to help observing its causal impact on psychological suffering and promote acceptance. More recently, Duff et al. (2016) investigated how a non-clinical adult population related to their thoughts. They found that higher believability (i.e., that is, how much they believed the thoughts to be ontologically true) of self-referential thoughts was associated with greater levels of psychological distress, cognitive fusion and experiential avoidance (Duff et al. 2016).

Over the past decade, there have been several studies measuring defusion techniques using different types of thoughts: such as a negative body image thought (Mandavia et al. 2015), negative self-referential thoughts (Deacon et al. 2011), negative (Masuda et al. 2010; Healy et al. 2008) and positive self-statements (Healy et al. 2008). However, all of these studies used exclusively two defusion techniques such as the repetition of the disturbing thought (Masuda et al. 2004, 2010) or the distancing defusion exercise “I am having the thought that” (Healy et al. 2008). In this study, we wanted to explore whether VR could be used as a tool or technique in which cognitive defusion could be implemented.

IT tools have been already used in first (for example, Emmelkamp et al. 2002; Krijn et al. 2007) and second wave generation (for example, Rizzo et al. 2004; Wiederhold and Wiederhold 2005) therapies and represent a new field that needs continuously major investigation. Although this technology has only been adopted recently in some clinical contexts, such as with depressed patients (Falconer et al. 2016), and with post-traumatic stress disorder (e.g., Montraghi et al. 2014), it could represent an important tool for clinicians.

Virtual reality (VR) is a computer-generated simulation of a three-dimensional environment that users can interact in. VR is of increasing interest to applied psychologists due to its potential for exposure learning (Rothbaum et al. 1997; Parsons and Rizzo 2008; Opris et al. 2012). A number of studies have shown that VRET (Virtual Reality Exposure Treatment) is an effective treatment against fear of flying (e.g., Krijn et al. 2007; North et al. 1997), or the fear of heights (Emmelkamp et al. 2002; Lamson and Meisner 1994), phobias (e.g., Emmelkamp et al. 2002) social anxiety disorders (e.g., Wallach et al. 2009; Wiederhold and Wiederhold 2005), post-traumatic stress disorder (e.g., Foa et al. 2009; Montraghi et al. 2014; Difede et al. 2002) panic disorder (Peñate et al. 2008), pain management (Shiri et al. 2013) and in the treatment of fibromyalgia (Botella et al. 2013).

The aim of the current study is to test the effect of a VR cognitive defusion technique for self-referential thoughts. The current study is the first to test the impact of a VR cognitive defusion technique on state cognitive defusion, willingness, believability, comfort and negativity of a negative self-referential thought. The intervention will be compared to an active control group that interacts with a VR software. Each participant, in both conditions, took part in the study for approximately 45 min. It is predicted that the defusion VR condition will reduce cognitive defusion, increase willingness and comfort in having a negative self-referential thought and reduce negativity and believability of the negative self-referential thought when compared to a an active control.

Method

Ethics

This study was ethically approved by the University College Dublin Ethics Committee (reference number HS-16-42).

Participants

Participants were recruited through posters and flyers at University College Dublin. Students from University College Dublin and the general public (N = 30) volunteered to participate in the study (23 Males; mean age = 23.91; SD = 6.41; 7 Females; mean age = 21.57; SD = 4.27). Participants were randomly allocated to either the intervention or control group using https://www.randomizer.org/ (n = 15 per group). All participants were over the age of 18 and had no visual impairments. No participants with epilepsy or a formally diagnosed prior mental health issue were eligible to participate.

Design

The study involved a 2 × 2 mixed experimental design, with group (i.e., defusion VR and Control VR) as the between-subject independent variable and time (pre and post) as the within-subject variable.

Materials

Oculus Rift and a leap motion: The VR software was designed specifically for the current study by the Behavior Labs Srls company in Catania (Italy) by one of the authors (ML). The VR equipment comprised of an Oculus Rift™ and a leap motion hand sensor kit. See Fig. 1 for an image of the laboratory set-up and Fig. 2 for a visual representation of the VR environment designed by the Behavior Labs Srls Company.

Measures

Target thought measure (Healy et al. 2008): All participants were instructed to generate a target negative thought rated at pre-intervention (T1) and post-intervention (T2) using a Likert scale (1–10) adapted from Healy et al. (2008) and used in Larsson et al. (2016). A score of 1 indicated that the thought was extremely “negative,” “believable,” “uncomfortable” and they were “unwilling to have the thought” while a score of 10 indicated that the thought was extremely “positive,” “unbelievable,” “comfortable” and they were “willing to have the thought.” Ratings were all scored from 1 to 10 rather than the 1–5 scale used in Larsson et al. (2016). Participants were instructed that the thought had to be higher than 9 (on a scale of 1–10) in terms of negativity, believability, how uncomfortable the thought was and how unwilling they were to have it.

State Cognitive Fusion Questionnaire (SCFQ, Bolderston et al. 2018). The state form of the short cognitive defusion questionnaire was employed pre- and post-VR. Each item of the SCFQ takes the form of a statement alluding to literality and entanglement with thoughts in order to measure broad cognitive fusion and defusion. A score of 1 indicates that the statement of the thought at present was “completely untrue,” while a score of 7 indicated that the thought was “completely true” at present. The measure has excellent internal reliability with a Cronbach’s alpha of 0.95 from a sample of 300 students (Bolderston et al. 2018). It has a test–retest reliability of 0.68 over 1 month. In terms of reliability, this is the expected level from a state measure given their sensitivity-to-change.

Procedure

Participants were asked to read through the information sheet and to sign the consent form if they were willing to participate in the experiment. They were then instructed to complete the SCFQ and the Target Thought Measure. In line with Larsson et al. (2016) in order to ensure that the thought selected was a negative self-referential, participants were instructed as follows:

Now pick a negative thought about yourself that would rate as EXTREMELY BELIEVABLE, EXTREMELY NEGATIVE, EXTREMELY UNCOMFORTABLE and that you are EXTREMELY UNWILLING to think. Make sure that it is not a thought about any physical aspect of yourself.

Before commencing with the VR equipment, the participants were provided with a demonstration regarding how to use the Oculus system with a standard audio interactive demonstration. This phase also allowed the participants to adapt themselves to the virtual environment. Each participant, in the VR defusion group and control group, was asked to identify only one of their disturbing thoughts (e.g., “I am stupid”) and to rate it using a Visual Analogue Scale (VAS). The thought was personal and selected by the participant. To make sure that participants selected the appropriate disturbing thought, each participant was asked individually to indicate how negative they would rate it. If the thought was not deemed relevant, negative, uncomfortable, believable or a thought that they were unwilling to have, then the researcher invited the participant to select another thought.

In the defusion VR condition, each participant was asked also if they felt comfortable enough to share the thought they had identified on the Target Thought measure. Each participant was asked to select a negative thought and asked if they wanted to share it or not. If the participant did not want to share the thought, then the researcher would have left the room in order to ensure privacy. The thought would still have been digitalized but not shared. No participant indicated that they did not want to share the thought. If the participant agreed to share the thought they were invited to digitalize the self-relevant negative thought (e.g., I am a failure’) into one or two words (maximum 35 characters). After the digitalization, the software reproduced the words in a suspended three-dimensional virtual space. In this 3D environment, participants were able to manipulate the object with their virtual hands via the VR environment and change its shape, size, color and gravity. Participants in the control group were instructed to digitalize one or a few words not related to the negative thought in the screen box. After the digitalization, the control participants could play with the VR freely. Once participants completed the VR part of the experiment they were instructed to complete the post-intervention measures.

Results

The means and standard deviation scores for each of the groups at T1 and T2 on the measures of Negativity, Believability, Comfortability, Willingness to have the negative thought and the State Cognitive Fusion were collated and are presented in Table 1.

Negativity of the target thought

For negativity of the target thought, a mixed 2 × 2 analysis of variance (ANOVA) revealed that a marginal Time × Group interaction, F(1,28) = 4.114; p = 0.052; η 2 p  = 0.128. Tests of simple effects were conducted to explore the interaction and revealed no difference between groups at T1, F(1,28) = 0; p > 0.05. However, there was a significant difference at T2 with the VR defusion group scoring higher than control, F(1,28) = 8.22; p < 0.05. Higher scores on the negativity rating scale refer to higher levels of positivity. The VR defusion group also were significantly higher at T2 than T1, F(1,28) = 11.24; p < 0.05. The control group did not differ from T1 to T2, F(1,28) = 0.234; p > 0.05.

Believability of the target thought

For believability of the target thought, a mixed 2 × 2 ANOVA revealed there was a significant Time × Group interaction, F(1,28) = 18.432; p = 0.001; η 2 p  = 0.397. Tests of simple effects were revealed no significant difference between groups at T1 F(1,28) = 0.576; p > 0.05. However, there was a significant difference at T2, with the VR defusion group rating higher than the control group, F(1,28) = 28.22; p < 0.05. The VR defusion group were also significantly higher at T2 than T1, F(1,28) = 50.087; p < 0.05. The control group did not differ from T1 to T2, F(1,28) = 1.01; p > 0.05.

Comfortability of the target thought

For comfortability of the target thought, a mixed 2 × 2 ANOVA revealed a marginal Time × Group interaction, F(1,28) = 3.13; p = 0.088; η 2 p  = 0.101. Given the marginal effect, and the pattern of means, tests of simple effects were explored. There was no statistically significant difference between groups at T1, F(1,28) = 0.776; p > 0.05. However, there was a significant difference at T2, with the VR defusion group higher than control group, F(1,28) = 11.37; p < 0.05. The VR defusion group was also significantly higher at T2 than T1, F(1,28) = 12.85; p < 0.05. The control group did not significantly differ from T1 to T2, F(1,28) = 1.195; p > 0.05.

Willingness of the target thought

For willingness of the target thought, a mixed 2 × 2 ANOVA revealed no significant interaction effect, F(1,28) = 1.65; p = 0.29; η 2 p  = 0.04. However, this analysis did reveal a significant main effect of time, F(1,28) = 3.476; p = 0.073; η 2 p  = 0.110, regardless of group. As an a priori prediction of the study was that there would be a significant difference in willingness to experience the target thought post-defusion intervention tests of simple effects were conducted to see if there were differences between groups at T1 and T2 and within groups from T1 to T2. However, it is important to note that given the fact that there was no interaction effect for the 2 × 2 ANOVA these results should be considered tentatively. Tests of simple effects also demonstrated that the VR defusion group were significantly higher than control at T1, F(1,28) = 11.09; p < 0.05, and at T2, F(1,28) = 23.52; p < 0.05. The VR defusion group were significantly higher at T2 than T1, F(1,28) = 4.33; p < 0.05. The control group did not differ from T1 to T2, F(1,28) = 0.31; p > 0.05.

State cognitive defusion

In order to determine whether the two groups differed in terms of state cognitive defusion from T1 to T2, a mixed 2 × 2 ANOVA was conducted with group as the between-subject factor (i.e., VR defusion and VR control) and time as the within-subject factor (i.e., pre and post). The ANOVA revealed no Group × Time interaction F(1,28) = 0.272; p = 0.606; η 2 p  = 0.010. As with willingness an a priori predictions of the study was that there would be a significant difference in state cognitive defusion post-defusion intervention and therefore follow-up tests of simple effects were conducted. However, it is important to note that given the fact that there was no interaction effect for the 2 × 2 ANOVA these results should be considered tentatively. In order to explore the results, simple effects analyses were conducted at both T1 and T2 revealing no difference between groups at T1, F(1,28) = 0.154; p > 0.05 or between groups at T2, F(1,28) = 1.28; p > 0.05. However, the VR defusion group was significantly lower at T2 than T1, F(1,28) = 5.69; p < 0.05, whereas the control group did not differ from T1 to T2, F(1,28) = 2.71; p > 0.05.

Discussion

The current study aimed to test the effectiveness of using VR as a tool, such as a standard exposure defusion technique for coping with negative thoughts and to investigate whether VR could facilitate a defusion effect. It is the first study to investigate the impact of VR on participants’ relationship to their negative self-referential thoughts. As hypothesized, the results of this study highlight how cognitive defusion mediated by VR is, in the short term, a technique that significantly reduces the believability and negativity and increases comfort and willingness associated with a disturbing thought. Specifically, the results indicated that a defusion VR intervention had significantly greater effects in terms of lowering believability, increasing comfort, reducing negativity and increasing willingness to have a self-generated target thought than a control group. That is, the defusion group shifted from rating their thoughts as believable, uncomfortable, negative and unwilling to have the thought to unbelievable, comfortable, less negative and willing to have the thought. For the defusion group, cognitive fusion decreased from pre- to post-intervention which did not occur for the control group.

The strength of this study is represented by exploring a new territory represented by the application of an ACT defusion exercise through VR. These findings provide preliminary evidence that the VR software is a useful tool that can be used to help people cope with negative self-referential thoughts. The authors’ aim was not to explore whether a 3D platform could create significant greater effect than a standard 2D exposure exercise.

The findings from the current study are in line with previous results of Larsson et al. (2016) who found that a brief defusion intervention had significantly greater effects on lowering believability, increasing comfort, and increasing willingness to have a negative self-generated target thought than a no-instruction control group. Moreover, the current study replicated the result that the defusion group shifted from rating their thought as believable, uncomfortable, and unwilling to unbelievable, comfortable, and willing.

There were some limitations to the current study. First, participants were not gender balanced. Previous research has observed contributing factors for gender differences in VR (Felnhofer et al. 2012). Future research should therefore investigate the mediating role of gender in the effect of VR-based defusion techniques. Second, the dependent measures were all self-report questionnaires. Contextual behavioral interventions aim to defuse clients from their thoughts in order to facilitate clients living in line with what matters, therefore, future research should test whether the VR defusion intervention impacts on behavior. Third, the participants recruited in the current study were undergraduate participants rather than a clinical sample. Although cognitive defusion studies (Deacon et al. 2011) and VR studies (Wallach et al. 2009) on clinical samples have been conducted, future research should compare the use of VR-based defusion techniques in clinical samples, and test their relative effectiveness with different samples. Finally, there was no follow-up test to determine whether the impact of the VR defusion intervention lasted across time. Future research should include a follow-up test that monitors the impact of the VR defusion technique over time. Despite these limitations, this study is important as it is the first to use VR as a potential intervention for dealing with unwanted negative thoughts with promising initial results. Future studies should make a comparison between a standard defusion exercise and a 3D platform and investigate whether a major effect is enhanced by a 3D VR equipment.
